channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Oil Prices Slump to 11-Year Lows in Asia and Europe
item.description: A glut of crude and the recent United Nations climate accord have both weighed on the market, factors exacerbated by OPEC’s keeping production high.
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.dc:creator: STANLEY REED
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: An oil platform in the Gulf of Mexico. Higher production from projects in the gulf is offsetting declines in shale oil production on shore.

item.title: 5 Coalition Members Killed in Suicide Attack in Afghanistan
item.description: A bomber struck a joint patrol of NATO and Afghan forces near the Bagram Air Base, north of Kabul.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL and JAWAD SUKHANYAR

item.title: Overlooked Safety Risks Added to Landslide in China, Reports Say
item.description: China’s rapid construction of new buildings, and the short life of many of those structures, have long created problems with unregulated dumping of construction waste.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Firefighters resting near collapsed buildings at the site of a landslide in the Chinese city of Shenzhen on Monday.

item.title: The Wrong Miss Universe Is (Briefly) Crowned
item.description: The host, Steve Harvey, took responsibility for mistakenly naming Miss Colombia, Ariadna Gutiérrez Arévalo. The true winner was Miss Philippines, Pia Alonzo Wurtzbach.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK
item.media:description: Steve Harvey at the Miss Universe pageant on Sunday.

item.title: U.S. Support of Gay Rights in Africa May Have Done More Harm Than Good
item.description: American money and diplomacy have opened opportunities for gay rights in Africa, but they have also made gay men and lesbians more visible and more vulnerable, critics say.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
United States Agency for International Development
Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI
item.media:credit: Glenna Gordon for The New York Times
item.media:description: A gay man in Bariga, a neighborhood in Lagos, Nigeria, who said he hides his identity from his friends and family.

item.title: After Cecil Furor, U.S. Aims to Protect Lions Through Endangered Species Act
item.description: Five months after the death of Cecil the lion spurred outrage, the new rules will make it more difficult for hunters to bring lion trophies into the United States.
item.dc:creator: ERICA GOODE
item.media:description: A lion in Kenya. In Kenya and some other African countries, hunting lions is illegal, but in others, tougher American import rules could reduce the number killed by hunters.

item.title: Spain’s Governing Party Loses Majority in Parliamentary Election
item.description: The conservative Popular Party and the main opposition Socialists both lost seats, putting the future of Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy in doubt.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy of the Popular Party casting his ballot on Sunday. Polls have predicted that his party will win the most votes, but lose its parliamentary majority.

item.title: French Ship Commands Naval Task Force in Strikes Against ISIS
item.description: The Nov. 13 terrorist attacks in Paris cast a spotlight on the carrier, which left its home port just five days later. Its deployment, however, had long been planned.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:credit: Army Sgt. First Class Clydell Kinchen/Department of Defense
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter aboard the Charles de Gaulle in the Persian Gulf on Saturday. The French carrier is the first non-American ship to take command of the Islamic State task force.

item.title: Yemen Peace Talks End With No End to Conflict
item.description: Negotiations brokered by the United Nations ended with no sign of a resolution to the civil war in Yemen and with the combatants engaged in some of their fiercest fighting in months, officials said.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM and SAEED AL-BATATI
item.media:description: Abdel-Malek al-Mekhlafi, Yemen's foreign minister, left, and Ezzaldin al-Asbahi, the human rights minister, in Switzerland on Sunday.

item.title: Memo From Afghanistan: Afghan Government Faces New Set of Rivals
item.description: The opposition to the government of President Ashraf Ghani, called the Council of Protection and Stability, already mirrors the struggling administration in its disunity.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL
item.media:description: From left, former President Hamid Karzai, President Ashraf Ghani, and Mr. Ghani’s coalition partner, Abdullah Abdullah.

item.title: State of Terror: Behind the Black Flag: The Recruitment of an ISIS Killer
item.description: Since the Syrian rebel leader Hassan Aboud joined ISIS, taking with him fighters and weapons, he has been behind a sprawling mix of battlefield action and crime.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: C. J. CHIVERS
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hassan Aboud, left, with Abu Ayman in 2013 when Mr. Aboud was leading sieges against Syrian Army positions from which soldiers were shelling the civilian population.

item.title: Hungary’s Migrant Stance, Once Denounced, Gains Some Acceptance
item.description: While repelled by the hate-mongering that has accompanied Prime Minister Viktor Orban’s positions, European leaders have begun to echo him on many points.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:description: Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary after a European Union summit meeting last week.

item.title: Egypt Releases Student in a Rare Bow to Public Pressure
item.description: Esraa al-Taweel, 23, who is also a photojournalist, was released after photos of her sobbing and hobbling on crutches went viral on social media.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Arab Network for Human Rights Information
item.dc:creator: AMINA ISMAIL

item.title: In Paris, Archivists Preserve Tokens of Grief
item.description: Tens of thousands of letters and drawings have been left at makeshift memorials after the Nov. 13 terrorist attacks.
item.dc:creator: LILIA BLAISE, AURELIEN BREEDEN and DAVID W. DUNLAP
item.media:description: Members of the City of Paris’s archival team gather notes, poems and drawings left at a memorial after the Nov. 13 attacks that killed 130 people there.

item.title: Israeli Minister Accused of Sexual Misconduct to Resign
item.description: Silvan Shalom, an important figure in Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s government, is being investigated by the police after at least seven women said he had sexually harassed them.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Facing Down Nigeria’s Ghosts
item.description: The silencing of history is dangerous. We remember the pains of our past to learn from them and to ensure they are not repeated.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: ENUMA OKORO

item.title: Commander of Hezbollah Freed by Israel Is Killed in Syria
item.description: The killing of Samir Kuntar, in a government-held neighborhood of Damascus, underscored the complexity of Syria’s civil war and the long arms of its many players.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID and ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: The site of an airstrike in Jaramana, a government-held neighborhood of Damascus, on Sunday. The Shiite militia Hezbollah said Israel had carried out the strike and that it killed Samir Kuntar, a Lebanese man who spent nearly 30 years in prison for a 1979 attack.

item.title: Landslide Hits Southern City, Sending Hundreds Fleeing, China Reports
item.description: At least 33 buildings are destroyed and 91 people are missing after a sea of earth struck an industrial district in the city of Shenzhen.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: Rescue efforts underway on Sunday in Shenzhen, China, after a landslide sent a sea of earth into an industrial district.

item.title: Lebanese Leader of Hezbollah Reportedly Killed in Syria
item.description: The killing of Samir Kuntar, in a government-held neighborhood of Damascus, underscored the complexity of Syria’s civil war and the long arms of its many players.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID and ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: The site of an airstrike in Jaramana, a government-held neighborhood of Damascus, on Sunday. The Shiite militia Hezbollah said Israel had carried out the strike and that it killed Samir Kuntar, a Lebanese man who spent nearly 30 years in prison for a 1979 attack.

item.title: Air France Flight Makes Emergency Landing in Kenya After ‘False Alarm’
item.description: The jetliner was en route to Paris when a passenger reported finding a suspicious device in the bathroom.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN
item.media:description: The Air France Boeing 777 aircraft after making an emergency landing in Mombasa.
